dmca.title: Spinning Yarns of Infringement?
dmca.body:
Dear [Private],

I am employed on an ad hoc basis by Ms Alice Starmore and her company
Virtual Yarns, to act as a contact in the first instance on all matters
concerning copyrights and trademarks.

I understand that you have established an internet discussion group that you
have titled the ALICE STARMORE OPEN FORUM.

I would like to draw your attention to the fact that the name ALICE STARMORE
is a registered trademark in Class 23: YARNS AND THREADS FOR TEXTILE
USE. In the USA it is registered at the United States Patent and Trademark
Office, Registration Number 2,344,881. The unlicensed use of the trademark
is not permitted, and such use can lead to remedial action in the US Federal
Courts, together with claims for damages caused and legal costs incurred.

It is also the case that using just part of the trademark can constitute an
infringement. eg. In a knitting context, "AS" or "ALICE" is sufficient to
denote ALICE STARMORE.

I must ask you to cease your unlicensed use of the trademark, and also to
desist from using it.

It is in your own interest to cease your unlicensed use of the trademark
immediately. Internet discussion groups are often noted for their immoderate
postings, and it is highly possible that actionable damage to the trademark
will be caused very quickly. It is also highly probable that members of your
forum will be vendors of yarns and will seek to promote their products. If
this occurs under the aegis of the ALICE STARMORE trademark, then it will
constitute an extremely serious infringement.

Should you wish to discuss any aspect of the above, or if any of the points
raised are unclear, please do not hesitate to contact me. It is Ms
Starmore's desire to resolve this matter in a constructive and harmonious
manner if possible, and she is willing to discuss it with you by phone if
you wish. She is aware that your actions may have been made in genuine
ignorance of the trademark status of her name.

However, this letter is written without prejudice to Ms Starmore's rights
and remedies, which are expressly reserved.

Yours sincerely,

[Private]
